Lead Story — Corporate Governance

Gerald Barkworth III Unveils New Corporate Language; Mandates All Memos Be Written in "Barklish"

By Theodore Ashworth, Senior Correspondent (Deceased 1994) Cpl.

In what analysts are calling "the most disruptive act of interspecies linguistics since Koko the gorilla asked for a kitten," CEO Gerald Barkworth III has formally introduced Barklish as the official corporate language of Barkworth & Associates, effective immediately.

The language consists of 14 words, 11 of which are "woof" at different pitches. The remaining three are "arf," a sustained whine, and the sound of a tail hitting a conference table.

"Woof woof WOOF woof woof-woof. Arf." — Gerald Barkworth III, Q4 Earnings Call (translated: "Revenue is a feeling, not a number. Treat?")
Facilities Report

Building Relocated 14 Times Last Week; Facilities Blames "The Building's Restless Spirit"

By Cynthia Park, Facilities Correspondent (Deceased 1989) Lt.

The corporate headquarters of Barkworth & Associates has moved to 14 distinct geographic locations since last Monday, including briefly occupying the same physical space as a Dave & Buster's in Topeka, Kansas.

"For about 40 minutes, our accounting department and their arcade section existed in the same location simultaneously," reported Janet Fell (deceased 1991). "I tried to play skee-ball. My hand went through the ball. Classic Tuesday."

Afterlife & Style

Haunting Your Former Desk: A Beginner's Guide to Territorial Spectralism

By Dr. Leslie Null, Paranormal HR (Deceased 1990) Maj.

With 847 spectral employees competing for 200 desks — and the desks themselves shifting between floors every time the building relocates — territorial disputes have reached an all-time high.

Last week, three ghosts from accounting attempted to occupy the same swivel chair simultaneously. The resulting ectoplasmic friction caused the chair to spin at 4,000 RPM and launch through the ceiling into what was, at the time, a Wendy's drive-through in Sacramento.

Opinion

Gerald Is a Good Boy and I Won't Hear Otherwise

By The Editorial Board (7 of 9 members deceased)

There has been a lot of talk recently — in the hallways, the spectral chat channels, the screaming void between dimensions — about whether Gerald Barkworth III is "qualified" to run this company. We at The Phantom Quarterly editorial board would like to state, for the record: he is a very good boy.

Yes, he ate the annual report. Yes, he chased the FedEx driver for six blocks. Yes, he has bitten two members of the SEC investigation team. But he also brought us a tennis ball yesterday, unprompted, and set it gently on the conference table. If that's not leadership, what is?

Interview

Exit Interview: "I Can't Exit. I'm a Ghost."

Conducted by HR Department (All Deceased)

HR: Thank you for sitting down with us, Kevin.

Kevin Barnes, Senior Analyst (Deceased 1991): I didn't sit down. I'm hovering. I've been hovering since Clinton's first term.

HR: Right. So, why are you leaving the company?

Kevin: I'm not leaving. I literally cannot leave. I've been trying to leave since 1997. The building keeps moving and I move with it. Last week I was in Portugal for 20 minutes. I don't speak Portuguese. I don't have a mouth.

Corrections & Retractions

Issue #13: We reported that the building was located in "rural Montana." It was, in fact, rural Mongolia. We regret the error. So does the yak.
Issue #13: The article "Gerald Celebrates 5 Years As CEO" incorrectly stated he was "a visionary leader." He is a golden retriever. The point stands, but for accuracy: golden retriever.
Issue #12: We printed the Barklish translation of "quarterly earnings" as "arf arf woof". The correct translation is "arf arf woof woof" (emphasis on the final woof). This distinction matters. We've been told.
Issue #11: Phil from IT is not, as we reported, "the worst ghost in the building." He is the second worst. We apologize to Phil and to Craig from Payroll (the actual worst).

Meetings
